_exec_summary.SummaryText:
C & M Supply, Inc. - Ruskin Plant

Ruskin, NE



1. Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies.

     

     The owners and employees of C & M Supply are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia or propane.  If an accidental release should occur, we are prepared to work with the local fire department and other emergency response authorities to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.



2. Facility Information.



     C & M Supply is an ag-supply business that sells fertilizers, farm chemicals, and fuels.  Our facility holds reportable quantities of both anhydrous ammonia stored in our 30,000 gallon tank is 120,000 pounds.  Our two propane storage tanks (18,000 gallons and 5,000 gallons) will hold a maximum of 83,000 poudds.



3. Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios



     Anhydrous ammonia worst case: The worst-case release scenario would be the release of the total contents of the 30,000 gallon storage tank as a gas over 10 minutes.  The maximum quanity rereleased would be 120,000 pounds, which represents the weight of the contents of the storage tank at 80 percent capacity as limited by company operating procedures.  The distance to the eddpoint (point of dispersion to 200 parts per million) is 4.7 miles.



     Anhdrous ammonia alternative: The alternative release scenario based on the most likely potential incident is a release from a break in a transfer hose.  The distance to the endpoint (point of dispersion to 200 parts per million) is 0.3 miles.



     Propane worst case : The worst-case release scenario would be the release and vapor cloud explosion of the contents of the largest storage tank.  The maximum quanity released would be 65,000 pounds, which represents the weight of the contents of the storage tank at 85 percent capacity as limited by company operating procedures.  The distance to the endpoint (point of overpressure of 1 PSI) is 0

.3 miles.



4. Accidental Release Prevention Program.



     For the handling of anhdrous ammonia, the facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia," K-61.11, published by The american National Standards Institute, Inc. (ANSI)< as well as the standards of the Occupation Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111,"Storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia." In addition, our storage tanks meet the standards of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME).



     For the hankling of propane, the facility has implemented the provisions of Pamphlet 58 of the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA). Our propane storage tanks also meet the standards of ASME.



5. Five-Year Accident History



     Our facility has not had any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia or propane in the last five years that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant prperty damage on site, or any known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.



6. Emergency Response Program



     The facility has prepared a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard 29 CFR 1910.38; has provided authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA; and has prepared a written emergency response program, in accordance with OSHA standard 29 CFR 1910.120, including pre-emergency planning and employee training.



7. Planned Changes To Improve Safety.



     Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions.  There are no additional specific anhydrous ammonia or propane safety recommendations for implementation at this time.
